raw_text:
Indie film nominations announced
 
 Mike Leigh's award-winning abortion drama Vera Drake has scooped seven nominations at this year's British Independent Film Awards.
 
 But the Venice winner faces stiff competition from Shane Meadows' critically acclaimed Dead Man's Shoes, which received eight nominations. Also in the running for a clutch of awards are My Summer of Love and the stalker drama Enduring Love. The winners will be announced at a ceremony in London on 30 November. The winners of the awards will be chosen by a jury chaired by Cold Mountain director Anthony Minghella and including actresses Cate Blanchett and Helena Bonham-Carter.
 
 The awards, which recognise independent film-making in Britain, were established seven years ago. "This year's nominees reflect the growing strength and diversity of British independent filmmaking," said BIFA founder and director Elliot Grove. Commenting on the diversity of the nominated films, he added: "Our selection committee had a harder time than ever narrowing down the field."
 
 Joining Vera Drake and Dead Man's Shoes in the running for best film are My Summer of Love, climbing documentary Touching the Void and zombie comedy Shaun of the Dead. Geoffrey Rush wins a best actor nomination for his role as Peter Sellers in the recent biopic The Life & Death of Peter Sellers.
 
 The Australian star faces competition from Daniel Craig (Enduring Love), Phil Davis (Vera Drake), Ian Hart (Blind Fight) and Dead Man's Shoes' star Paddy Considine. Considine is also nominated for a best supporting actor award for My Summer of Love. A rare US nominee, Scarlett Johansson, is among this year's best actress contenders for her role in Girl with a Pearl Earring.
 
 Fellow nominees include Imelda Staunton (Vera Drake), Natalie Press (My Summer of Love), Anne Reid (The Mother) and Eva Birthistle (Ae Fond Kiss... ). Shane Meadows and Kevin McDonald, both former winners of the Douglas Hickox Award (for Best Directorial Debut) won best director nominations. Seasoned film-makers Roger Michell, Mike Leigh and Pavel Pavlikowsky challenge them to the award. Harry Potter author JK Rowling will receive a special award for her contribution to the industry.
llama3.2:1b: Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" has seven nominations at this year's British Independent Film Awards.
Other nominees include "Dead Man's Shoes", "My Summer of Love", and "Enduring Love".
The winners will be announced on November 30, with a jury chaired by Anthony Minghella.
llama3.2:3b: Mike Leigh's Vera Drake has seven British Independent Film Awards nominations while Shane Meadows' Dead Man's Shoes is tied with eight nominations.
The winners, including best film and acting awards, will be announced at London on November 30 by a jury chaired by Anthony Minghella.

Other nominees include My Summer of Love, Touching the Void, Shaun of the Dead, Geoffrey Rush for his role in The Life & Death of Peter Sellers, Daniel Craig for Enduring Love, and Scarlett Johansson for Girl with a Pearl Earring.
gemma2:2b: Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" received seven BIFA nominations.
"Dead Man's Shoes", "My Summer of Love" and "Enduring Love" also received multiple nominations.
The winners of the awards, chosen by a jury chaired by Anthony Minghella and including Cate Blanchett and Helena Bonham-Carter, will be announced on November 30th.
Other notable nominees include "The Life & Death of Peter Sellers,"  "Touchng the Void", "Shaun of the Dead," and "Girl with a Pearl Earring."

British Indie Film Awards announced 7 nominees including Vera Drake (Mike Leigh's abortion drama) and Dead Man's Shoes, which won eight nominations.
Other contenders include My Summer of Love, Enduring Love, Enduring Love (Cate Blanchett), Shaun of the Dead, and Touching the Void.
Some nominees face stiff competition from other films like Shane Meadows' "Dead Man's Shoes" and various documentaries.
Other nominees include Daniel Craig as Peter Sellers in "Enduring Love," Anna Kendrick for a supporting role in "My Summer of Love," and Emma Watson for an acting nomination in "Enduring Love."

The winners of the awards, which recognize independent film-making in Britain, were chosen by a jury chaired by Cold Mountain director Anthony Minghella and including actresses Cate Blanchett and Helena Bonham-Carter.

The nominees include Vera Drake and Dead Man's Shoes (8 nominations), My Summer of Love (3 nominations), Touching the Void and Shaun of the Dead (2 nominations), Peter Sellers in The Life & Death of Peter Sellers (1 nomination), Girl with a Pearl Earring (1 nomination), Daniel Craig (1 nomination), Phil Davis (1 nomination), Ian Hart (1 nomination), Blind Fight (1 nomination), Eva Birthistle (1 nomination), Anne Reid (1 nomination) and Scarlett Johansson (1 nomination).

The awards will take place in London on November 30 with independent film-making being recognised with numerous nominations, including My Summer of Love, climbing documentary Touching the Void and zombie comedy Shaun of the Dead.
The Australian star, Daniel Craig, faces competition from Philip Davis (Vera Drake), Ian Hart (Blind Fight) and Dead Man's Shoes' star Paddy Considiere, among this year's best actress contentors.

Fellow nominés include Imeldas Stauntoon (Vera Drake), Natalie Press (My Summer of Love), Anne Reid (The Mother) and Eva Birthistle (Ae Fond Kiiss... ), with Shane Meadows and Kevin McDonald, both former winners of the Douglas Hickox Award, also nominated.
The IFA will hold its ceremony in London on November 30 and will be chaired by BIFA founder and director Elliot Grove.
JK Rowling will receive a special award for her contribution to the industry.

Additionally, My Summer of Love and Enduring Love have also received nominations.

stablelm-zephyr:3b: Mike Leigh's Vera Drake received seven nominations at the British Independent Film Awards, facing competition from Shane Meadows' Dead Man's Shoes, My Summer of Love, and Enduring Love.
The winners will be announced on November 30th, selected by a jury chaired by Anthony Minghella and including Cate Blanchett and Helena Bonham-Carter.

stablelm2:1.6b: Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" received seven nominations at this year's British Independent Film Awards, with Dead Man's Shoes receiving eight nominations.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The British Independent Film Awards (BIFA) has announced nominations for its 2004 ceremony, held in London on November 30.
Mike Leigh's Vera Drake leads with seven nominations, while Shane Meadows' Dead Man's Shoes follows closely with eight nods.
Other notable entries include My Summer of Love and Enduring Love.
The winners will be selected by a jury led by Anthony Minghella, featuring Cate Blanchett and Helena Bonham-Carter.
This year's diverse nominees reflect the flourishing strength and variety of British independent filmmaking, according to BIFA founder Elliot Grove.
Alongside Vera Drake and Dead Man's Shoes in best film contention are My Summer of Love, Touching the Void (documentary), and Shaun of the Dead.

Geoffrey Rush is nominated for The Life & Death of Peter Sellers as best actor, competing against Daniel Craig (Enduring Love), Phil Davis (Vera Drake), Ian Hart (Blind Fight), and Paddy Considine (My Summer of Love).
Australian star Rush also earns a nomination for best supporting actor in My Summer of Love.

US actress Scarlett Johansson joins the best actress race with Girl with a Pearl Earring, alongside Imelda Staunton (Vera Drake), Natalie Press (My Summer of Love), Anne Reid (The Mother), and Eva Birthistle (Ae Fond Kiss).
Shane Meadows and Kevin McDonald, both past Douglas Hickox Award recipients for best directorial debut, are nominated alongside seasoned filmmakers Roger Michell, Mike Leigh, and Pavel Pavlikowsky.
BIFA will also honor JK Rowling with a special award for her contribution to the film industry.

Best film nominees include Vera Drake, Dead Man's Shoes, My Summer of Love, Touching the Void, and Shaun of the Dead.
Geoffrey Rush, Daniel Craig, and Paddy Considine are among the best actor nominees, while Scarlett Johansson, Imelda Staunton, and Natalie Press compete for best actress.
Shane Meadows and Kevin McDonald are nominated for best director alongside Roger Michell, Mike Leigh, and Pavel Pavlikowsky.
JK Rowling will receive a special award for her industry contributions.
